heading: Terrible Tragedy near Katamatite MOTHER AND THREE CHILDREN MURDERED. THREE VICTIMS DEAD, ONE LIVING. INDIAN HAWKER ARRESTED.
articleText:
Terrible Tragedy near Katamatite

MOTHER AND THREE CHILDREN

MURDERED.

THREE VICTIMS DEAD, ONE LIVING.

INDIAN HAWKER ARRESTED..

News came to hand yesterday after- noon of a terrible tragedy having taken place in the morning at a farm- house known as Aston's, about five miles on the Youarang side of Kata- matite, where a woman named Mrs Pugsley, the wife of David Pugsley, was shot, as well as three children, with a saloon rifle while in bed.

From phone reports we learn that a Hindoo named Buttan Singh camped at Pugsley's on Tuesday night, and was there early yesterday morning when Mr Pugsley went to work on a distant part of the farm, but on the latter's return at about 8 o'clock he found that the Hindoo had decamped, and on going inside was horrified to find that his wife and three children had been murdered while in bed, the

mother and two children being dead,   and one child seriously wounded.

After attending as well as he could to the living one Mr Pugsley went into Katamatite and informed Con- stable Fowles, who at once commenced investigations and notified adjoining police stations. Search parties went out to look for the suspected man, and at 1.15 p.m. we learned by phone that Constable Slater, of Dookie, together with Messrs H. Mulcahy, T. Hughes,

and A. Tait, at 3 o'clock found the   accused near Allatt's farm, about 3 miles from Katamatite, where he was arrested. Buttan Singh did not resist arrest, though he had a loaded saloon rifle with him. Accused at one time

lived at Yarroweyah.  

Tho tragedy has caused a feeling of horror throughout the district, as well as resentment against the licensing of

colored hawkers.

During the past few months sums amounting to £5 4s 6d have been sent to the Patriotic Fund from the local State School, and yesterday a parcel was sent to the Red Cross Society con-

taining 1 Nightingale, 3 handerchiefs,   4 Balaclava caps, 8 pair of socks, 8 pairs of cuffs and 4 pairs of mittens.

During the year the pupils of the senior grades at the Cobram school were engaged in a wheat growing com- petition for a trophy donated by the Honorables W. L. Baillieu and Frank Clarke. After growing vigorously for some time, the plot was, a few weeks ago, destroyed by a trespassing

beast.
